results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: prelude to revolution, 1904-1905
results.creator_credit: Sam Spiegel, Franklin J. Schaffner and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Focuses on the years 1904-1905. Shows some of the causes of the Russian revolution that were visible more than a decade before Lenin arrived at the Finland station. Reveals the extreme contrasts of Russia, the role of the Czar, the workers, the revolutionaries and the peasants. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman, Laurence Olivier.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra
results.creator_credit: Armorer Wason, Granite Film, Granada International Productions and Michael Beckham
results.brief_description: For over 70 years the story of Russia’s last Tsar, Nicholas II and his Empress, Alexandra has exercised a poignant magic. Presented by His Royal Highness Prince Michael of Kent, this documentary delves into the imperial archives held in Moscow and St Petersberg, once sealed by the Secret Police and forbidden to all but a handful of curators. The archives reveal intimate diaries and letters of the Romanovs, their photograph albums, records of state visits and political intrigue.

results.title: Nice time
results.brief_description: An observation of couples and youths at night around London’s famous Piccadilly Circus. Influenced by the Free Cinema movement, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner allow the camera to observe the scenes of people milling in front of cinemas, walking around the Circle and attempting to get into night clubs. There is no voice over, and instead, it is the observational mise-en-scene and the almost relaxed detachment of the observing camera that creates a leisurely but intriguing glimpse into everyday pleasure and life. The decision of the Swiss directors, Goretta and Tanner, to travel to the UK to involve themselves in Free Cinema was an indication of the immense influence the movement was having on documentary filmmaking, an influence that was to lead to the radical aesthetics of “cinema verite”.

results.title: Nicaragua no pasaran
results.brief_description: An award-winning documentary that focuses on the guerrilla leader, political fugitive and revolutionary hero, Tomas Borge. Borge, the only surviving member of the original Sandinista movement, is Minister of the Interior in the nine man National Directorate, the collective leadership that governs Nicaragua. He recounts his experiences during his internment under the US-backed Somoza dictatorship. Explains the events which led to the formation of the revolutionary Sandinista movement and its rise to power in 1979. Also explores accusations made by Ronald Reagan that the Sandinista government is involved in activities that threaten to destabilise Central America. Contains b&w sequences. Photography by Geoffrey Simpson.

results.title: Nicaragua 1979: scenes from the revolution
results.brief_description: Documents the Sandinista uprising from the general strike of June 1979 through the first hundred days of reconstruction after the victory. A fast-paced “on the spot” film which eloquently captures the furious demise of the Somoza dynasty in its desperate attempt to turn back the tide of history, and which also paints a powerful portrait of the forces at work within the Nicaraguan revolution.

results.title: Niagara for sale
results.brief_description: Niagara Peninsula is a fertile strip of land that produces most of Canada’s fruit supply, however the factors that make it a productive farming area also attracts industry and developers who cover the land with cement. This film presents the views of farmers, developers, scientists and politicians on the competition for natural resources.

results.title: Ngurunderi: a Ngarrindjeri Dreaming
results.creator_credit: John Dick, Pepper Studios, South Australian Film Corporation, S A Museum and Max Pepper
results.brief_description: This Aboriginal myth, based on Albert Karloan’s version as told to Professor Berndt 1939-40, belongs to the Ngarrindjeri people of South Australia. It tells how Ngurunderi formed the landscape and the wildlife from the junction of the Murray Darling Rivers to Kangaroo Island where he left the world to become a bright star in the Milky Way. The Dreaming is re-enacted in the actual location it describes.
